Award.AwardTitle: CRII: SaTC: A Language Based Approach to Hybrid Mobile App Security

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The last few years have seen an explosive growth in the share of hybrid mobile apps worldwide, coinciding with the increasing ubiquity of HTML5. Hybrid app frameworks allow mobile developers to design app code using web technologies alone, and supply native and bridge code (APIs for accessing device resources) necessary for instant porting to several mobile platforms.

This research will develop techniques to mitigate critical security and privacy vulnerabilities in hybrid app frameworks, by creating an airtight security model robust against bridge exploits, and minimizing the overall attack surface of the hybrid framework. In a global society increasingly reliant on mobile technology, mobile app security constitutes a pressing responsibility, and impacts several sections of society, including children. This project will provide a significant contribution towards meeting this challenge. Case studies, practical examples, and research experience gained from this project will be integrated into graduate-level courses, especially Master's and certificate programs in cyber-security. Additionally, interesting techniques and examples developed in this project will be incorporated into curricula specifically targeted for women in computing initiatives, with the objective of attracting and retaining more women in computing fields.

This research will explore extension of powerful language-based security techniques, in-lined reference monitoring (IRM) and static analysis, to the novel and significant problem domain of hybrid app security. The research has three major goals: 1) defining a systematic mapping of the hybrid app attack surface, and establishing a class of security policies that target effective language-based enforcement; 2) adapting the IRM approach to the complex, cross-platform hybrid software stack, including effective complete mediation for seamless protection and tamper-proofing of the monitoring system; 3) designing an effective static-analysis algorithm to infer fine-grained permissions-regions for pages in a hybrid app. These permissions regions will improve bridge access granularity, and serve as security policy models for integration into the IRM framework for enforcement. These goals will serve towards building automatic protection technologies for hybrid apps, transparent enforcement that preserves the functionality of safe apps, and retroactive enforcement that can be applied to vulnerable apps in the wild.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: 

Hybrid mobile apps are cross-platform, web-based mobile apps that are written using web technologies such as HTML and JavaScript (JS). This popular technology allows mobile apps to be write-once-run-anywhere, saving substantial resources required to develop different versions of the same app for Android, iOS, etc. Much recent research in the field demonstrates that the inclusion of web content in mobile apps dramatically increases the attack surface and exacerbates security issues of these apps. Additionally, lately many IoT manufacturers have adopted the hybrid app model for creating “smart home” companion mobile apps (apps that pair with and control the smart home device), thereby extending the web attack surface to smart home systems.


This project introduces HybridGuard, a novel in-lined reference monitoring (IRM) policy enforcement framework that can enforce principal-based, stateful policies, on multiple origins without modifying the hybrid frameworks or mobile platforms. HybridGuard can mitigate a significant class of attacks caused by potentially malicious JavaScript (JS) code included from third-party domains, including ads running inside the app. HybridGuard also provides a mechanism and policy patterns for app developers to specify fine-grained policies for multiple principals, such as local JS, remote trusted JS, and remote untrusted JS. HybridGuard is implemented entirely in JavaScript and is inserted as a script via the <script> tag inside a web page instead of the actual scripts that are required by the application; the actual scripts are loaded using HybridGuard to track the origin of the scripts; therefore, it can be easily adapted for other hybrid frameworks or mobile platforms without modification of these frameworks or platforms. 


HybridGuard provides the following unique capabilities:

  1. Fine-grained, principal-based security and privacy policies:  Apart from traditional safety policies such as blacklists, whitelists and history-based policies, HybridGuard can also enforce novel policy classes such as volume bound policy, usage duration policy, and location-based policy. 

  2. Policy-patterns (templates): This permission specification allows app developers to customize for different parties over single permission. We integrate our permission specification into an app at the development phase; however, by design, it allows end-users to adjust parameters at runtime to protect their privacy. 

  3. Platform-agnostic and lightweight: Our experimental results demonstrate that the framework is compatible with various hybrid development frameworks over two major mobile platforms, with lightweight overhead. We check HybridGuard’s compatibility with Apache Cordova, Onsen UI, Intel XDK and Framework 7, for two major platforms (Android and iOS).

  4. Evaluation: We selected and modified 40 real-world Android apps to include our framework prototype, re-packaged the apps, and tested the apps for performance and policy implementation on a real Android device. Most of the apps were downloaded from Google Play Store, while some were downloaded from third-party app stores such as apkpure.com. Our prototype code for HybridGuard and the apps are available using the following link: https://github.com/sridhar-research-lab/hybridguard-2019 

Many hybrid companion IoT apps (apps paired with smart home IoT devices) can be exploited to launch serious cyberattacks against the IoT device, or the smartphone itself, to compromise user privacy. This project led to an attack surface analysis and proof-of-concept exploits of hybrid IoT companion apps, covering insecure app development practices such as using outdated Android SDKs and libraries, misconfigured Webview, Content Security Policies and whitelists, using outdated Cordova SDKs, unsafe usage of inline scripts, on-event handlers, JavaScript APIs, iframes, and eval() functions, and usage of unencrypted storage. The PI is currently (at the time of this report) working on extending HybridGuard to the hybrid companion app security space.

The broader impacts of the project include:

  1. A new course, “Web-based Mobile and IoT Firmware Security”, that provides students an introduction to recent security topics in web-based mobile and IoT software security. The course has been taught thrice at the time of writing of this report, with the third time being fully online; the course is critical to the UNCC Software and Information Systems Department’s MS in Cyber Security and a new Information Security and Privacy Fully Online graduate certificate.

  2. Publications of the results of the research in workshop, conference, and journal papers, and three poster presentations.

  3. Datasets and code of the project made publicly available on Github; publications, datasets and code will be made available on the PI’s website as well.

  4. This project led to the doctoral dissertation of one PhD student; additionally, three UG and eight MS students, including two female students, contributed to various aspects of the project. 

  5. Active dissemination of the research by the PI as seminar lectures in several universities and industry research labs. 

  6. Results of this project also paved the way for an NSF SaTC EDU grant awarded in 2020 that focuses on developing an inclusive, engaging pedagogy for teaching hybrid mobile app security.
